analyzed: dvividhāni iha bhūtāni trasāni sthāvarāṇi ca
translated: Here there are two kinds of beings, moving and unmoving.

analyzed: trasānām trividhā yoniḥ aṇḍa sveda jarāyu jāḥ
translated: Of the moving, the birth is of three kinds, from eggs, sweat, and wombs.

original: trasānāṃ khalu sarveṣāṃ śreṣṭhā rājañ jarāyujāḥ
analyzed: trasānām khalu sarveṣām śreṣṭhāḥ rājam jarāyu jāḥ
translated: Of all the moving beings, O king, those born from wombs are the best.

original: jarāyujānāṃ pravarā mānavāḥ paśavaś ca ye
analyzed: jarāyu jānām pravarāḥ mānavāḥ paśavaḥ ca ye
translated: Among those born from wombs, humans and animals are the foremost.

analyzed: nānā rūpāṇi bibhrāṇāḥ teṣām bhedāḥ caturdaśa
translated: Bearing various forms, they are divided into fourteen kinds.

analyzed: araṇya vāsinaḥ sapta sapta eṣām grāma vāsinaḥ
translated: Seven live in the forest, seven in the village.

analyzed: siṃha vyāghra varāhāḥ ca mahiṣāḥ vāraṇāḥ tathā
translated: Lions, tigers, boars, buffaloes, and elephants,

original: ṛkṣāś ca vānarāś caiva saptāraṇyāḥ smṛtā nṛpa
analyzed: ṛkṣāḥ ca vānarāḥ ca eva sapta āraṇyāḥ smṛtāḥ nṛpa
translated: O king, the bears and monkeys are said to be the seven wild animals.

analyzed: gauḥ ajaḥ manujaḥ meṣaḥ vāji aśvatara gardabhāḥ
translated: The cow, goat, man, sheep, horse, ass and mule are the domestic animals.

original: ete grāmyāḥ samākhyātāḥ paśavaḥ sapta sādhubhiḥ
analyzed: ete grāmyāḥ samākhyātāḥ paśavaḥ sapta sādhubhiḥ
translated: These are declared to be the seven domestic animals by the virtuous.

original: ete vai paśavo rājan grāmyāraṇyāś caturdaśa
analyzed: ete vai paśavaḥ rājan grāmya āraṇyāḥ caturdaśa
translated: O king, these are the fourteen domestic and wild animals.

analyzed: veda uktāḥ pṛthivīpāla yeṣu yajñāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: They are mentioned in the Vedas, O protector of the earth, and sacrifices are established in them.

analyzed: grāmyāṇām puruṣaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ siṃhaḥ ca araṇya vāsinām
translated: Among the domestic animals, man is the best, and among the wild animals, the lion.

analyzed: sarveṣām eva bhūtānām anyonyena abhijīvanam
translated: All beings live on each other.

original: udbhijjāḥ sthāvarāḥ proktās teṣāṃ pañcaiva jātayaḥ
analyzed: udbhid jāḥ sthāvarāḥ proktāḥ teṣām pañca eva jātayaḥ
translated: The immobile beings are said to be born from sprouts, and they have five species.

analyzed: vṛkṣa gulma latā vallyaḥ tvac sārāḥ tṛṇa jātayaḥ
translated: Trees, shrubs, creepers, vines, plants with milky sap, and grasses.

analyzed: eṣām viṃśatiḥ eka ūnā mahābhūteṣu pañcasu
translated: Of these, nineteen are included in the five great elements.

analyzed: caturviṃśatiḥ uddiṣṭāḥ gāyatrī loka saṃmatā
translated: The twenty-four are declared to be the Gayatri revered by the world.

original: ya etāṃ veda gāyatrīṃ puṇyāṃ sarvaguṇānvitām
analyzed: yaḥ etām veda gāyatrīm puṇyām sarva guṇa anvitām
translated: One who knows this Gayatri, which is auspicious and endowed with all good qualities,

original: tattvena bharataśreṣṭha sa lokān na praṇaśyati
analyzed: tattvena bharata śreṣṭha sa lokān na praṇaśyati
translated: Truly, O best of the Bharata lineage, he does not perish in this world.

original: bhūmau hi jāyate sarvaṃ bhūmau sarvaṃ praṇaśyati
analyzed: bhūmau hi jāyate sarvam bhūmau sarvam praṇaśyati
translated: Everything is born on the earth, and everything perishes on the earth.

original: bhūmiḥ pratiṣṭhā bhūtānāṃ bhūmir eva parāyaṇam
analyzed: bhūmiḥ pratiṣṭhā bhūtānām bhūmiḥ eva parāyaṇam
translated: The earth is the support of beings, and the earth is their ultimate refuge.

original: yasya bhūmis tasya sarvaṃ jagat sthāvarajaṅgamam
analyzed: yasya bhūmiḥ tasya sarvam jagat sthāvara jaṅgamam
translated: For whoever owns the earth, owns the entire world with its moving and unmoving creatures.

analyzed: tatra abhigṛddhāḥ rājānaḥ vinighnanti itaretaram
translated: It is for the sake of that earth that kings slay one another.

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

analyzed: nadīnām parvatānām ca nāmadheyāni saṃjaya
translated: O Sanjaya, tell me the names of the rivers, mountains,

original: tathā janapadānāṃ ca ye cānye bhūmim āśritāḥ🔽pramāṇaṃ ca pramāṇajña pṛthivyā api sarvaśaḥ
analyzed: tathā janapadānām ca ye ca anye bhūmim āśritāḥ  pramāṇam ca pramāṇa jña pṛthivyāḥ api sarvaśas
translated: and also of the countries and whatever else is situated on the earth.🔽O knower of what is right, tell me in detail the extent of the earth

analyzed: nikhilena samācakṣva kānanāni ca saṃjaya
translated: and also the forests, O Sanjaya.

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca  pañca imāni mahā rāja mahābhūtāni saṃgrahāt
translated: Sanjaya said:🔽O great king, these five great elements, which are the basis of the universe,

original: jagat sthitāni sarvāṇi samāny āhur manīṣiṇaḥ
analyzed: jagat sthitāni sarvāṇi samāni āhuḥ manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: are said to be the same by the wise.

original: bhūmir āpas tathā vāyur agnir ākāśam eva ca
analyzed: bhūmiḥ āpaḥ tathā vāyuḥ agniḥ ākāśam eva ca
translated: Earth, water, air, fire and space -

analyzed: guṇa uttarāṇi sarvāṇi teṣām bhūmiḥ pradhānataḥ
translated: all of them have qualities that increase progressively, and earth is the most important among them.

original: śabdaḥ sparśaś ca rūpaṃ ca raso gandhaś ca pañcamaḥ
analyzed: śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca rūpam ca rasaḥ gandhaḥ ca pañcamaḥ
translated: Sound, touch, form, taste and smell as the fifth -

original: bhūmer ete guṇāḥ proktā ṛṣibhis tattvavedibhiḥ🔽śabdaḥ sparśaś ca rūpaṃ ca rasaś cāpi prakīrtitāḥ
analyzed: bhūmeḥ ete guṇāḥ proktāḥ ṛṣibhiḥ tattva vedibhiḥ  śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca rūpam ca rasaḥ ca api prakīrtitāḥ
translated: these are said to be the qualities of earth by the sages who know the truth.

original: catvāro 'psu guṇā rājan gandhas tatra na vidyate
analyzed: catvāraḥ psu guṇāḥ rājan gandhaḥ tatra na vidyate
translated: Sound, touch, form and taste are declared to be the four qualities of water, O king, smell is not found there.

original: śabdaḥ sparśaś ca rūpaṃ ca tejaso 'tha guṇās trayaḥ
analyzed: śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca rūpam ca guṇāḥ trayaḥ
translated: Sound, touch, and form are the three qualities of fire.

original: śabdaḥ sparśaś ca vāyos tu ākāśe śabda eva ca
analyzed: śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca vāyoḥ tu ākāśe śabdaḥ eva ca
translated: Sound and touch are the qualities of air, and sound alone of space.

original: ete pañca guṇā rājan mahābhūteṣu pañcasu
analyzed: ete pañca guṇāḥ rājan mahābhūteṣu pañcasu
translated: These five qualities, O king, exist in the five great elements,

analyzed: vartante sarva lokeṣu yeṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: in which all the worlds are established.

original: anyonyaṃ nābhivartante sāmyaṃ bhavati vai yadā
analyzed: anyonyam na abhivartante sāmyam bhavati vai yadā
translated: They do not act upon each other when they are in a state of equilibrium.

analyzed: yadā tu viṣamībhāvam āviśanti parasparam
translated: But when they enter into a state of inequality with each other,

analyzed: tadā dehaiḥ dehavantaḥ vyatirohanti na anyathā
translated: then embodied beings, through their bodies, rise and fall, and not otherwise.

original: bhāvaṃ na ca bhajantas te nāśaṃ gacchanti nānyathā
analyzed: bhāvam na ca bhajantaḥ te nāśam gacchanti na anyathā
translated: They do not attain existence or non-existence, and not otherwise.

analyzed: ānupūrvyāt vinaśyanti jāyante ca anupūrvaśas
translated: They perish in due order, and are born in due order.

original: sarvāṇy aparimeyāni tad eṣāṃ rūpam aiśvaram
analyzed: sarvāṇi aparimeyāni tat eṣām rūpam aiśvaram
translated: All of them are immeasurable, and that is their divine form.

original: tatra tatra hi dṛśyante dhātavaḥ pāñcabhautikāḥ
analyzed: tatra tatra hi dṛśyante dhātavaḥ pāñcabhautikāḥ
translated: The five elements are seen everywhere.

analyzed: teṣām manuṣyāḥ tarkeṇa pramāṇāni pracakṣate
translated: Men declare their measures by reasoning.

original: acintyāḥ khalu ye bhāvā na tāṃs tarkeṇa sādhayet
analyzed: acintyāḥ khalu ye bhāvāḥ na tān tarkeṇa sādhayet
translated: Those things which are indeed inconceivable cannot be established by reasoning.

original: prakṛtibhyaḥ paraṃ yat tu tad acintyasya lakṣaṇam
analyzed: prakṛtibhyaḥ param yat tu tat acintyasya lakṣaṇam
translated: That which is beyond the primary elements is the characteristic of the inconceivable.

analyzed: sudarśanam pravakṣyāmi dvīpam te kuru nandana
translated: O descendant of Kuru, I will now describe to you the island of Sudarshana.

analyzed: parimaṇḍalaḥ mahā rāja cakra saṃsthitaḥ
translated: O great king, that island is circular and shaped like a wheel,

analyzed: nadī jala praticchannaḥ parvataiḥ ca abhra saṃnibhaiḥ
translated: Covered with rivers and water, and with mountains resembling clouds,

original: puraiś ca vividhākārai ramyair janapadais tathā
analyzed: puraiḥ ca ramyaiḥ janapadaiḥ tathā
translated: With cities of various forms, and with delightful countries,

analyzed: vṛkṣaiḥ puṣpa phala upetaiḥ saṃpanna dhana dhānyavān
translated: And with trees full of flowers and fruits, rich in wealth and grain,

analyzed: lāvaṇena samudreṇa samantāt parivāritaḥ
translated: Surrounded on all sides by the salt ocean.

original: yathā ca puruṣaḥ paśyed ādarśe mukham ātmanaḥ
analyzed: yathā ca puruṣaḥ paśyet ādarśe mukham ātmanaḥ
translated: Just as a man would see his own face in a mirror,

analyzed: evam sudarśana dvīpaḥ dṛśyate candra maṇḍale
translated: So the Sudarshana island is seen in the lunar orb.

original: dvir aṃśe pippalas tatra dvir aṃśe ca śaśo mahān
analyzed: dvis aṃśe pippalaḥ tatra dvis aṃśe ca śaśaḥ mahān
translated: In two parts there is the pippala tree there, and in two parts the great hare,

analyzed: sarva oṣadhi samāvāpaiḥ sarvatas paribṛṃhitaḥ
translated: Surrounded on all sides by the collection of all herbs.

original: āpas tato 'nyā vijñeyā eṣa saṃkṣepa ucyate
analyzed: āpaḥ tatas nyāḥ vijñeyāḥ eṣa saṃkṣepaḥ ucyate
translated: The water beyond that should be known. This is said in brief.

original: tato 'nya ucyate cāyam enaṃ saṃkṣepataḥ śṛṇu
analyzed: tatas nyaḥ ucyate ca ayam enam saṃkṣepataḥ śṛṇu
translated: And this other one is said. Listen to it in brief.

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

original: ukto dvīpasya saṃkṣepo vistaraṃ brūhi saṃjaya🔽vidhivad buddhimaṃs tvayā
analyzed: uktaḥ dvīpasya saṃkṣepaḥ vistaram brūhi saṃjaya
translated: The summary of the island has been stated. Tell me in detail, O Sanjaya,

analyzed: tattva jñaḥ ca asi sarvasya
translated: By you, who are wise and know the truth of everything.

analyzed: yāvat bhūmi avakāśaḥ yam dṛśyate śaśalakṣaṇe
translated: As far as this space on the earth is seen with the mark of a hare,

original: tasya pramāṇaṃ prabrūhi tato vakṣyasi pippalam
analyzed: tasya pramāṇam prabrūhi tatas vakṣyasi pippalam
translated: Tell me about its extent, and then you can speak about the fruit.

analyzed: vaiśaṃpāyanaḥ uvāca
translated: Vaishampayana said:

original: evam uktaḥ sa rājñā tu saṃjayo vākyam abravīt
analyzed: evam uktaḥ sa rājñā tu saṃjayaḥ vākyam abravīt
translated: Thus addressed by the king, Sanjaya spoke these words:

analyzed: prāc āyatāḥ mahā rāja ṣaṭ ete ratna parvatāḥ
translated: O great king, these six mountains of jewels extend from east to west,

original: sthitā samudram ākramya avarūḍhā bhavaṃs tataḥ
analyzed: sthitā samudram ākramya avarūḍhā bhavan tatas
translated: standing in the ocean, and rising from it.

analyzed: avagāḍhāḥ hi ubhayatas samudrau pūrva paścimau
translated: They extend to the eastern and western oceans.

original: himavān hemakūṭaś ca niṣadhaś ca nagottamaḥ
analyzed: himavān hemakūṭaḥ ca niṣadhaḥ ca naga uttamaḥ
translated: The Himalayas, the Hemakūṭa, and the Niṣadha, the best of mountains,

original: nīlaś ca vaiḍūryamayaḥ śvetaś ca rajataprabhaḥ
analyzed: nīlaḥ ca vaiḍūrya mayaḥ śvetaḥ ca rajata prabhaḥ
translated: the blue mountain of lapis lazuli, and the white mountain shining like silver,

analyzed: sarvadhātuvinaddhaḥ ca śṛṅgavān nāma parvataḥ
translated: and the mountain named Śṛṅgavān, composed of all minerals,

analyzed: ete vai parvatāḥ rājan siddha cāraṇa sevitāḥ
translated: these mountains, O king, are frequented by the Siddhas and Cāraṇas.

analyzed: teṣām antara viṣkambhaḥ yojanāni sahasraśas
translated: The distance between them is thousands of yojanas.

original: tatra puṇyā janapadās tāni varṣāṇi bhārata
analyzed: tatra puṇyāḥ janapadāḥ tāni varṣāṇi bhārata
translated: There are holy countries, O Bharata, and those are the Varṣas (regions).

analyzed: vasanti teṣu sattvāni nānā jātīni sarvaśas
translated: In them dwell various kinds of creatures.

analyzed: gandharva ādyāḥ vasanti sma hi apsaraḥ gaṇa sevitāḥ
translated: The Gandharvas and others dwell there, attended by the celestial nymphs.

original: idaṃ tu bhārataṃ varṣaṃ tato haimavataṃ param
analyzed: idam tu bhāratam varṣam tatas haimavatam param
translated: This is the Bhārata Varṣa, beyond it is the Haimavat Varṣa.

analyzed: tatas kiṃpuruṣa āvāsam varṣam himavataḥ param
translated: Beyond the Himalayas is the Varṣa inhabited by the Kiṃpuruṣas.

analyzed: hemakūṭāt param ca eva harivarṣam pracakṣate
translated: Beyond Hemakūṭa, they call it Harivarsha.

analyzed: dakṣiṇena tu nīlasya niṣadhasya uttareṇa ca
translated: To the south of Nīla and to the north of Niṣadha,

analyzed: prāc āyataḥ mahā rāja mālyavān nāma parvataḥ
translated: O great king, there is a mountain called Mālyavān, extending from east to west.

analyzed: tatas param mālyavataḥ parvataḥ gandhamādanaḥ
translated: Beyond that, beyond Mālyavat, is the mountain Gandhamādana.

analyzed: tena eva krama yogena parvataḥ gandhamādanaḥ
translated: In the same order, the mountain Gandhamādana

analyzed: parimaṇḍalaḥ tayoḥ madhye meruḥ kanakaparvataḥ
translated: is circular in shape, and in the middle of those two is Mount Meru, the golden mountain.

analyzed: āditya taruṇa ābhāsaḥ vidhūmaḥ iva pāvakaḥ
translated: Shining like the rising sun, like a fire without smoke,

analyzed: yojanānām sahasrāṇi ṣoḍaśa adhas kila smṛtaḥ
translated: it is said to be sixteen thousand yojanas below,

analyzed: uccais ca catura aśītiḥ yojanānām mahīpate
translated: and, O lord of the earth, it is eighty-four thousand yojanas high.

original: ūrdhvam antaś ca tiryak ca lokān āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
analyzed: ūrdhvam antar ca tiryak ca lokān āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
translated: It stands above, within, and across, enveloping the worlds.

original: tasya pārśve tv ime dvīpāś catvāraḥ saṃsthitāḥ prabho
analyzed: tasya pārśve tu ime dvīpāḥ catvāraḥ saṃsthitāḥ prabho
translated: On its sides, there are four islands situated, O lord.

original: bhadrāśvaḥ ketumālaś ca jambūdvīpaś ca bhārata
analyzed: bhadrāśvaḥ ketumālaḥ ca jambūdvīpaḥ ca bhārata
translated: Bhadrāśva, Ketumāla, Jambūdvīpa, and Bhārata.

original: ketumālaś caturthaś ca meroḥ paścimataḥ sthitaḥ
analyzed: ketumālaḥ caturthaḥ ca meroḥ paścimatas sthitaḥ
translated: The fourth, Ketumāla, is situated to the west of Meru.

analyzed: uttarāḥ ca eva kuravaḥ kṛta puṇya pratiśrayāḥ
translated: And the Uttarakurus, the abode of those who have performed meritorious deeds.

analyzed: vihagaḥ sumukhaḥ yatra suparṇasya ātmajaḥ kila
translated: Where, it is said, the bird Sumukha, the son of Suparṇa,

original: sa vai vicintayām āsa sauvarṇān prekṣya vāyasān
analyzed: sa vai vicintayām āsa sauvarṇān prekṣya vāyasān
translated: He thought, seeing the golden crows,

analyzed: meruḥ uttama madhyānām adhamānām ca pakṣiṇām
translated: Meru is the best, middling and lowest of the birds,

original: aviśeṣakaro yasmāt tasmād enaṃ tyajāmy aham
analyzed: a viśeṣa karaḥ yasmāt tasmāt enam tyajāmi aham
translated: Since it makes no distinction, therefore I abandon it.

analyzed: tam ādityaḥ nuparyeti satatam jyotiṣām patiḥ
translated: The sun always goes around it, the lord of the luminaries,

original: candramāś ca sanakṣatro vāyuś caiva pradakṣiṇam
analyzed: candramāḥ ca sa nakṣatraḥ vāyuḥ ca eva pradakṣiṇam
translated: And the moon with the stars, and the wind clockwise.

analyzed: sa parvataḥ mahā rāja divya puṣpa phala anvitaḥ
translated: That mountain, great king, is endowed with divine flowers and fruits,

analyzed: bhavanaiḥ āvṛtaḥ sarvaiḥ jāmbūnada mayaiḥ śubhaiḥ
translated: Surrounded on all sides by auspicious golden mansions.

analyzed: tatra deva gaṇāḥ rājan gandharva asura rākṣasāḥ
translated: There, O king, hosts of gods, Gandharvas, Asuras and Rakshasas,

analyzed: apsaraḥ gaṇa saṃyuktāḥ śaile krīḍanti nityaśas
translated: Together with the celestial nymphs, always play on the mountain.

original: tatra brahmā ca rudraś ca śakraś cāpi sureśvaraḥ
analyzed: tatra brahmā ca rudraḥ ca śakraḥ ca api sura īśvaraḥ
translated: There Brahma, Rudra, and also Shakra, the lord of the gods,

analyzed: sametya vividhaiḥ yajñaiḥ yajante na eka dakṣiṇaiḥ
translated: Having assembled, worship with various sacrifices, with many gifts.

original: tumburur nāradaś caiva viśvāvasur hahā huhūḥ
analyzed: tumburuḥ nāradaḥ ca eva viśvāvasuḥ hahā huhūḥ
translated: Tumburu, Narada, Vishvavasu, Haha and Huhu,

analyzed: abhigamya amara śreṣṭhāḥ stavai stunvanti ca abhibho
translated: Having approached, the best of the immortals, praise with hymns, O lord.

analyzed: saptarṣayaḥ mahātmānaḥ kaśyapaḥ ca prajāpatiḥ
translated: The seven great sages, and Kashyapa, the lord of creatures,

original: tatra gacchanti bhadraṃ te sadā parvaṇi parvaṇi
analyzed: tatra gacchanti bhadram te sadā parvaṇi parvaṇi
translated: There they go, for your welfare, on every lunar parva day.

original: tasyaiva mūrdhany uśanāḥ kāvyo daityair mahīpate
analyzed: tasya eva mūrdhani uśanāḥ kāvyaḥ daityaiḥ mahīpate
translated: O lord of the earth, on his head is Ushanas, the son of Kavya, born of the demons.

analyzed: tasya hi imāni ratnāni tasya ime ratna parvatāḥ
translated: These jewels belong to him, these jewel mountains belong to him.

original: tasmāt kubero bhagavāṃś caturthaṃ bhāgam aśnute
analyzed: tasmāt kuberaḥ bhagavān caturtham bhāgam aśnute
translated: Therefore, the illustrious Kubera obtains a fourth part.

analyzed: tatas kalā aṃśam vittasya manuṣyebhyaḥ prayacchati
translated: From that, he gives a sixteenth part of wealth to humans.

analyzed: pārśve tasya uttare divyam sarva ṛtu kusumam śivam
translated: On its northern side is a divine, auspicious, and flowery forest,

original: karṇikāravanaṃ ramyaṃ śilājālasamudgatam🔽tatra sākṣāt paśupatir divyair bhūtaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ
analyzed: karṇikāra vanam ramyam śilā jāla samudgatam  tatra sākṣāt paśupatiḥ divyaiḥ bhūtaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ
translated: a beautiful Karnikara forest rising from a mass of rocks.🔽There, the Lord of beings himself, surrounded by divine beings,
the illustrious consort of Uma, the creator of beings, sports.

analyzed: karṇikāra mayīm mālām bibhrat pāda avalambinīm
translated: Wearing a garland of Karnikara flowers hanging down to his feet,

original: tribhir netraiḥ kṛtoddyotas tribhiḥ sūryair ivoditaiḥ
analyzed: tribhiḥ netraiḥ kṛta uddyotaḥ tribhiḥ sūryaiḥ iva uditaiḥ
translated: illuminated by three eyes, as if by three rising suns.

analyzed: tam ugra tapasaḥ siddhāḥ suvratāḥ satya vādinaḥ
translated: The ascetics of fierce austerities, of good vows, and truthful speech,

translated: There is a great and eternal rose-apple tree named Sudarśana.

original: tasya nāmnā samākhyāto jambūdvīpaḥ sanātanaḥ🔽yojanānāṃ sahasraṃ ca śataṃ ca bharatarṣabha
analyzed: tasya nāmnā samākhyātaḥ jambūdvīpaḥ sanātanaḥ  yojanānām sahasram ca śatam ca bharata ṛṣabha
translated: It is after its name that the eternal Rose-Apple Island is known.

analyzed: pariṇāhaḥ tu vṛkṣasya phalānām rasa bhedinām
translated: The circumference of the tree, which bears fruits that burst open with juice, is fifteen hundred and one hundred aratnis.

original: patamānāni tāny urvyāṃ kurvanti vipulaṃ svanam
analyzed: patamānāni tāni urvyām kurvanti vipulam svanam
translated: As they fall on the ground, they make a loud noise.

original: muñcanti ca rasaṃ rājaṃs tasmin rajatasaṃnibham
analyzed: muñcanti ca rasam rājan tasmin rajata saṃnibham
translated: O king! They release a juice that resembles silver.

original: tasyā jambvāḥ phalaraso nadī bhūtvā janādhipa
analyzed: tasyāḥ jambvāḥ phala rasaḥ nadī bhūtvā janādhipa
translated: O lord of men! The juice of that rose-apple tree becomes a river

analyzed: indragopaka saṃkāśam jāyate bhāsvaram tu tat

analyzed: taruṇa āditya varṇāḥ ca jāyante tatra mānavāḥ

analyzed: nāmnā saṃvartakaḥ nāma kālāgniḥ bharata ṛṣabha

analyzed: tathā mālyavataḥ śṛṅge pūrve pūrva anta gaṇḍikā

analyzed: yojanānām sahasrāṇi pañcāśat mālyavān sthitaḥ

analyzed: mahārajata saṃkāśāḥ jāyante tatra mānavāḥ

translated: And to the north of the Ocean of Milk, the Lord

analyzed: yathā guṇa balam ca api trivargasya mahā phalam

analyzed: duhyet dhenuḥ kāmadhuk ca bhūmiḥ samyak anuṣṭhitā

analyzed: anyonyasya avalumpanti sārameyāḥ iva āmiṣam

analyzed: rājānaḥ bharata śreṣṭha bhoktu kāmāḥ vasuṃdharām

analyzed: tasmāt parigrahe bhūmeḥ yatante kuru pāṇḍavāḥ

original: sāmnā dānena bhedena daṇḍenaiva ca pārthiva
analyzed: sāmnā dānena bhedena daṇḍena eva ca pārthiva
translated: By conciliation, by gifts, by dissension, and by punishment, O king,

translated: Therefore, from that greatly valorous Bhargava, invincible in battle,

analyzed: tejaḥ vīrya balaiḥ bhūyām śikhaṇḍī drupada ātmajaḥ
translated: Therefore, Shikhandi, the son of Drupada, is certainly greater in energy, prowess and strength than that greatly valorous Bhargava, invincible in battle,

analyzed: yaḥ śūram kṛtinam yuddhe sarva śāstra viśāradam
translated: who killed the brave and skilled one in battle, the knower of all scriptures,

analyzed: parama astra vidam vīram jaghāna bharata ṛṣabham
translated: the heroic one skilled in supreme weapons, the bull among the Bharata race.

original: ke vīrās tam amitraghnam anvayuḥ śatrusaṃsadi
analyzed: ke vīrāḥ tam amitra ghnam anvayuḥ śatru saṃsadi
translated: Which heroes followed that slayer of enemies into the assembly of enemies?

original: śaṃsa me tad yathā vṛttaṃ yuddhaṃ bhīṣmasya pāṇḍavaiḥ
analyzed: śaṃsa me tat yathā vṛttam yuddham bhīṣmasya pāṇḍavaiḥ
translated: Tell me how the battle between Bhishma and the Pandavas unfolded.

original: yoṣeva hatavīrā me senā putrasya saṃjaya
analyzed: yoṣā iva hata vīrā me senā putrasya saṃjaya
translated: My army, O Sanjaya, is like a woman whose hero has been slain,

original: agopam iva codbhrāntaṃ gokulaṃ tad balaṃ mama
analyzed: agopam iva ca udbhrāntam go kulam tat balam mama
translated: and that army of mine is like a herd of cows without a protector.

analyzed: pauruṣam sarva lokasya param yasya mahā āhave
translated: Whose manliness was supreme among all the people in that great battle,

original: parāsikte ca vas tasmin katham āsīn manas tadā
analyzed: parāsikte ca vaḥ tasmin katham āsīt manaḥ tadā
translated: when he was struck down by you, what was the state of their minds then?

original: jīvite 'py adya sāmarthyaṃ kim ivāsmāsu saṃjaya
analyzed: jīvite pi adya sāmarthyam kim iva asmāsu saṃjaya
translated: O Sanjaya, what is the point of our remaining alive now?

analyzed: ghātayitvā mahā vīryam pitaram loka dhārmikam
translated: Having caused the death of my father, who was greatly valorous and righteous in the world,

original: agādhe salile magnāṃ nāvaṃ dṛṣṭveva pāragāḥ
analyzed: agādhe salile magnām nāvam dṛṣṭvā iva pāra gāḥ
translated: like those who have seen a boat sunk in the fathomless waters,

original: bhīṣme hate bhṛśaṃ duḥkhān manye śocanti putrakāḥ
analyzed: bhīṣme hate bhṛśam duḥkhāt manye śocanti putrakāḥ
translated: I think my sons must be grieving deeply, thinking of Bhishma's death.

analyzed: adri sāra mayam nūnam su dṛḍham hṛdayam mama
translated: My heart must surely be made of the essence of mountains, very firm,

original: yac chrutvā puruṣavyāghraṃ hataṃ bhīṣmaṃ na dīryate
analyzed: yat śrutvā puruṣa vyāghram hatam bhīṣmam na dīryate
translated: Hearing that the tiger among men, Bhishma, has been killed, it does not break apart,

original: yasminn astraṃ ca medhā ca nītiś ca bharatarṣabhe
analyzed: yasmin astram ca medhā ca nītiḥ ca bharata ṛṣabhe
translated: In whom there was weapon, intelligence, and policy, O bull among the Bharata lineage,

original: aprameyāṇi durdharṣe kathaṃ sa nihato yudhi
analyzed: aprameyāṇi durdharṣe katham sa nihataḥ yudhi
translated: How was that immeasurable and invincible one killed in battle?

original: na cāstreṇa na śauryeṇa tapasā medhayā na ca
analyzed: na ca astreṇa na śauryeṇa tapasā medhayā na ca
translated: Not by weapon, not by valor, not by austerity, not by intelligence,

original: na dhṛtyā na punas tyāgān mṛtyoḥ kaś cid vimucyate
analyzed: na dhṛtyā na punar tyāgāt mṛtyoḥ kaḥ cit vimucyate
translated: Not by steadfastness, nor by renunciation, does anyone escape death.

analyzed: kālaḥ nūnam mahā vīryaḥ sarva loka duratyayaḥ
translated: Time is indeed of great power, irresistible to all the worlds,

original: yatra śāṃtanavaṃ bhīṣmaṃ hataṃ śaṃsasi saṃjaya
analyzed: yatra śāṃtanavam bhīṣmam hatam śaṃsasi saṃjaya
translated: Where you tell me that Shantanu's son Bhishma has been killed, O Sanjaya.

analyzed: putra śoka abhisaṃtaptaḥ mahat duḥkham a cintayan
translated: Tormented by grief for his sons, he thought of great sorrow,

original: āśaṃse 'haṃ purā trāṇaṃ bhīṣmāc chaṃtanunandanāt🔽yadādityam ivāpaśyat patitaṃ bhuvi saṃjaya
analyzed: āśaṃse ham purā trāṇam bhīṣmāt śaṃtanu nandanāt  yadā ādityam iva apaśyat patitam bhuvi saṃjaya
translated: I had hoped for protection from Bhishma, the son of Shantanu, in the past,🔽When I saw Shantanu's son Bhishma, the grandfather of the Kurus, fallen on the ground like the sun, O Sanjaya,

original: duryodhanaḥ śāṃtanavaṃ kiṃ tadā pratyapadyata🔽nāhaṃ sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ vā buddhyā saṃjaya cintayan
analyzed: duryodhanaḥ śāṃtanavam kim tadā pratyapadyata  na aham sveṣām pareṣām vā buddhyā saṃjaya cintayan
translated: What did Duryodhana do to Shantanu's son then?🔽I, O Sanjaya, thinking with my mind of our own and the enemy's troops,

original: śeṣaṃ kiṃ cit prapaśyāmi pratyanīke mahīkṣitām
analyzed: śeṣam kim cit prapaśyāmi pratyanīke mahīkṣitām
translated: Do not see even a remnant of the kings in the opposing army.

analyzed: dāruṇaḥ kṣatra dharmaḥ yam ṛṣibhiḥ saṃpradarśitaḥ
translated: This terrible Kshatriya dharma was shown by the sages,

original: yatra śāṃtanavaṃ hatvā rājyam icchanti pāṇḍavāḥ
analyzed: yatra śāṃtanavam hatvā rājyam icchanti pāṇḍavāḥ
translated: Where the Pandavas desire the kingdom after killing Shantanu's son,

original: vayaṃ vā rājyam icchāmo ghātayitvā pitāmaham
analyzed: vayam vā rājyam icchāmaḥ ghātayitvā pitāmaham
translated: Or we desire the kingdom after killing the grandfather,

analyzed: kṣatra dharme sthitāḥ pārthāḥ na aparādhyanti putrakāḥ
translated: The Parthas abide by the duty of a kshatriya, my sons do not offend.

original: etad āryeṇa kartavyaṃ kṛcchrāsv āpatsu saṃjaya
analyzed: etat āryeṇa kartavyam kṛcchrāsu āpatsu saṃjaya
translated: This is what should be done by a noble one in difficult situations, O Sanjaya.

original: parākramaḥ paraṃ śaktyā tac ca tasmin pratiṣṭhitam🔽anīkāni vinighnantaṃ hrīmantam aparājitam
analyzed: parākramaḥ param śaktyā tat ca tasmin pratiṣṭhitam  anīkāni vinighnantam hrīmantam aparājitam
translated: Valour is supreme within one's ability, and that is established in him.

analyzed: katham śāṃtanavam tāta pāṇḍu putrāḥ nyapātayan
translated: How did the sons of Pandu bring down Shantanu's son, the modest one who was invincible, who was destroying the armies?

original: kathaṃ yuktāny anīkāni kathaṃ yuddhaṃ mahātmabhiḥ
analyzed: katham yuktāni anīkāni katham yuddham mahātmabhiḥ
translated: How were the armies arranged? How did the battle unfold with those great souls?

original: kathaṃ vā nihato bhīṣmaḥ pitā saṃjaya me paraiḥ
analyzed: katham vā nihataḥ bhīṣmaḥ pitā saṃjaya me paraiḥ
translated: Or how was Bhishma, my father, killed by the enemy?

original: duryodhanaś ca karṇaś ca śakuniś cāpi saubalaḥ
analyzed: duryodhanaḥ ca karṇaḥ ca śakuniḥ ca api saubalaḥ
translated: And what did Duryodhana, Karna, Shakuni the son of Subala,

original: duḥśāsanaś ca kitavo hate bhīṣme kim abruvan🔽yac charīrair upastīrṇāṃ naravāraṇavājinām🔽śaraśaktigadākhaḍgatomarākṣāṃ bhayāvahām
analyzed: duḥśāsanaḥ ca kitavaḥ hate bhīṣme kim abruvan  yat śarīraiḥ upastīrṇām nara vāraṇa vājinām  śara śakti gadā khaḍga tomara akṣām bhaya āvahām
translated: And the deceitful Duhshasana say when Bhishma was killed?🔽Which the wicked gamblers entered, the assembly hall difficult to approach in battle, strewn with the bodies of men, elephants and horses,

original: prāviśan kitavā mandāḥ sabhāṃ yudhi durāsadām
analyzed: prāviśan kitavāḥ mandāḥ sabhām yudhi durāsadām
translated: Frightening with arrows, javelins, clubs, swords, spikes and axes,

analyzed: prāṇa dyūte pratibhaye ke dīvyanta nara ṛṣabhāḥ
translated: In the terrible gambling with lives, which bulls among men did not gamble?

original: ke 'jayan ke jitās tatra hṛtalakṣā nipātitāḥ
analyzed: ke jayan ke jitāḥ tatra hṛta lakṣāḥ nipātitāḥ
translated: Who were victorious and who were defeated there, who had their aims thwarted and were brought down?

original: anye bhīṣmāc chāṃtanavāt tan mamācakṣva saṃjaya
analyzed: anye bhīṣmāt śāṃtanavāt tat mama ācakṣva saṃjaya
translated: Other than Shantanu's son Bhishma, tell me that, Sanjaya.

original: na hi me śāntir astīha yudhi devavrataṃ hatam
analyzed: na hi me śāntiḥ asti iha yudhi devavratam hatam
translated: For I have no peace here, having heard that Devavrata was killed in battle.

original: pitaraṃ bhīmakarmāṇaṃ śrutvā me duḥkham āviśat
analyzed: pitaram bhīma karmāṇam śrutvā me duḥkham āviśat
translated: Hearing of my father of terrible deeds, sorrow has overcome me.

original: ārtiṃ me hṛdaye rūḍhāṃ mahatīṃ putrakāritām
analyzed: ārtim me hṛdaye rūḍhām mahatīm putra kāritām
translated: The great grief born in my heart from my sons,

analyzed: tvam siñcan sarpiṣā iva agnim uddīpayasi saṃjaya
translated: You are pouring it, like ghee on a fire, Sanjaya, you are fanning it.

analyzed: mahāntam bhāram udyamya viśrutam sārvalaukikam
translated: Having taken up a great burden, renowned and known to all the worlds,

original: taṃ vimagnaṃ naravyāghraṃ bhīṣmaṃ śaṃsasi saṃjaya
analyzed: tam vimagnam nara vyāghram bhīṣmam śaṃsasi saṃjaya
translated: You are telling me that Bhishma, that tiger among men, has been submerged, Sanjaya.

original: dṛṣṭvā vinihataṃ bhīṣmaṃ manye śocanti putrakāḥ
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā vinihatam bhīṣmam manye śocanti putrakāḥ
translated: Seeing Bhishma slain, I think my sons are grieving.

analyzed: śroṣyāmi tāni duḥkhāni duryodhana kṛtāni aham
translated: I will hear those sorrows caused by Duryodhana.

original: tasmān me sarvam ācakṣva yad vṛttaṃ tatra saṃjaya
analyzed: tasmāt me sarvam ācakṣva yat vṛttam tatra saṃjaya
translated: Therefore, tell me everything that happened there, Sanjaya,

analyzed: saṃgrāme pṛthivīśānām mandasya a buddhi saṃbhavam
translated: In the battle of the lords of the earth, born from the foolish one's lack of understanding.

original: apanītaṃ sunītaṃ vā tan mamācakṣva saṃjaya
analyzed: apanītam su nītam vā tat mama ācakṣva saṃjaya
translated: Whether it was ill-advised or well-advised, tell me that, Sanjaya.

original: yat kṛtaṃ tatra bhīṣmeṇa saṃgrāme jayam icchatā
analyzed: yat kṛtam tatra bhīṣmeṇa saṃgrāme jayam icchatā
translated: What was done there by Bhishma, desiring victory in the battle,

original: tejoyuktaṃ kṛtāstreṇa śaṃsa tac cāpy aśeṣataḥ
analyzed: tejaḥ yuktam kṛtāstreṇa śaṃsa tat ca api aśeṣatas
translated: Endowed with energy, skilled in weapons, tell that also in its entirety.

analyzed: yathā tat abhavat yuddham kuru pāṇḍava senayoḥ
translated: How that battle took place between the armies of the Kurus and Pandavas,

original: krameṇa yena yasmiṃś ca kāle yac ca yathā ca tat
analyzed: krameṇa yena yasmin ca kāle yat ca yathā ca tat
translated: In what order, at what time, and what it was like,

original: yac ca yasmiṃś ca kāle ca vṛttaṃ yac ca yathā ca tat
analyzed: yat ca yasmin ca kāle ca vṛttam yat ca yathā ca tat
translated: And what happened at what time, and how it happened,

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca
translated: Sanjaya said:

analyzed: tvad yuktaḥ yam anupraśnaḥ mahā rāja yathā arhasi
translated: O great king, this question is rightly asked by you, as you deserve.

original: na tu duryodhane doṣam imam āsaktum arhasi
analyzed: na tu duryodhane doṣam imam āsaktum arhasi
translated: But you should not attribute this fault to Duryodhana,

original: ya ātmano duścaritād aśubhaṃ prāpnuyān naraḥ
analyzed: yaḥ ātmanaḥ duścaritāt aśubham prāpnuyāt naraḥ
translated: A man who suffers misfortune due to his own misconduct,

original: enasā tena nānyaṃ sa upāśaṅkitum arhati🔽mahārāja manuṣyeṣu nindyaṃ yaḥ sarvam ācaret
analyzed: enasā tena na anyam saḥ upāśaṅkitum arhati  mahā rāja manuṣyeṣu nindyam yaḥ sarvam ācaret
translated: Should not suspect anyone else for that sin.🔽O great king, one who commits all censurable acts among men,

analyzed: sa vadhyaḥ sarva lokasya ninditāni samācaran
translated: Is worthy of being killed by all people, committing as he does censurable acts.

analyzed: nikāraḥ nikṛti prajñaiḥ pāṇḍavaiḥ tvad pratīkṣayā
translated: The Pandavas, who are deceitful in their wisdom, have suffered insults while waiting for you,

original: anubhūtaḥ sahāmātyaiḥ kṣāntaṃ ca suciraṃ vane🔽hayānāṃ ca gajānāṃ ca śūrāṇāṃ cāmitaujasām
analyzed: anubhūtaḥ saha amātyaiḥ kṣāntam ca su ciram vane  hayānām ca gajānām ca śūrāṇām ca amita ojasām
translated: Along with their ministers, and have patiently endured it for a long time in the forest.

original: pratyakṣaṃ yan mayā dṛṣṭaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yogabalena ca
analyzed: pratyakṣam yat mayā dṛṣṭam dṛṣṭam yoga balena ca
translated: I have seen with my own eyes and with the power of yoga,🔽The destruction of horses, elephants, and heroes of immeasurable prowess.

original: śṛṇu tat pṛthivīpāla mā ca śoke manaḥ kṛthāḥ
analyzed: śṛṇu tat pṛthivīpāla mā ca śoke manaḥ kṛthāḥ
translated: Listen to that, O lord of the earth, and do not set your mind on sorrow.

original: diṣṭam etat purā nūnam evaṃbhāvi narādhipa
analyzed: diṣṭam etat purā nūnam evaṃbhāvi narādhipa
translated: This was certainly ordained in the past, O lord of men, to turn out this way.🔽O king, the Pandavas are not to be blamed in this matter.

analyzed: namaskṛtvā pituḥ te ham pārāśaryāya dhīmate
translated: Having paid homage to your father, the wise son of Parashara,

original: yasya prasādād divyaṃ me prāptaṃ jñānam anuttamam
analyzed: yasya prasādāt divyam me prāptam jñānam anuttamam
translated: By whose grace I have attained the supreme and divine knowledge,

original: dṛṣṭiś cātīndriyā rājan dūrāc chravaṇam eva ca
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ ca atīndriyā rājan dūrāt śravaṇam eva ca
translated: The ability to see and hear beyond the senses, O king,

analyzed: para cittasya vijñānam atīta anāgatasya ca
translated: The knowledge of the minds of others, and of the past and future,

analyzed: vyutthita utpatti vijñānam ākāśe ca gatiḥ sadā
translated: The ability to emerge from and enter the womb, and to always move through the sky,

analyzed: śastraiḥ asaṅgaḥ yuddheṣu vara dānāt mahātmanaḥ
translated: And to be unslain by weapons in battles, by the boon of the great-souled one.

analyzed: śṛṇu me vistareṇa idam vicitram parama adbhutam
translated: Listen to me as I relate this wonderful and extraordinary story in detail,

analyzed: bhāratānām mahat yuddham yathā abhūt loma harṣaṇam
translated: The great battle of the Bharatas, which made the hair stand on end.

original: teṣv anīkeṣu yat teṣu vyūḍheṣu ca vidhānataḥ
analyzed: teṣu anīkeṣu yat teṣu vyūḍheṣu ca vidhānataḥ
translated: When those armies were arrayed according to rule,

analyzed: duryodhanaḥ mahā rāja duḥśāsanam atha abravīt
translated: Maharaja Duryodhana spoke to Duhshasana, saying,

analyzed: duḥśāsana rathāḥ tūrṇam yujyantām bhīṣma rakṣiṇaḥ
translated: Duhshasana, quickly yoke the chariots for the protection of Bhishma,

original: anīkāni ca sarvāṇi śīghraṃ tvam anucodaya
analyzed: anīkāni ca sarvāṇi śīghram tvam anucodaya
translated: And quickly urge on all the armies.

analyzed: ayam mā samanuprāptaḥ varṣa pūga abhicintitaḥ
translated: This has come upon me, thought of for many years,

analyzed: pāṇḍavānām sa sainyānām kurūṇām ca samāgamaḥ
translated: The encounter of the Pandavas with their armies and the Kurus.

original: nātaḥ kāryatamaṃ manye raṇe bhīṣmasya rakṣaṇāt
analyzed: na atas kāryatamam manye raṇe bhīṣmasya rakṣaṇāt
translated: I do not think there is any task greater than the protection of Bhishma in battle.

original: hanyād gupto hy asau pārthān somakāṃś ca sasṛñjayān
analyzed: hanyāt guptaḥ hi asau pārthān somakān ca sa sṛñjayān
translated: Protected by him, he would have killed the Parthas, the Somakas and the Srinjayas.

original: abravīc ca viśuddhātmā nāhaṃ hanyāṃ śikhaṇḍinam
analyzed: abravīt ca viśuddha ātmā na aham hanyām śikhaṇḍinam
translated: And the pure-souled one said, I will not kill Shikhandi,

original: śrūyate strī hy asau pūrvaṃ tasmād varjyo raṇe mama
analyzed: śrūyate strī hi asau pūrvam tasmāt varjyaḥ raṇe mama
translated: for it is heard that he was a woman before, therefore he is to be avoided in battle by me.

original: tasmād bhīṣmo rakṣitavyo viśeṣeṇeti me matiḥ
analyzed: tasmāt bhīṣmaḥ rakṣitavyaḥ viśeṣeṇa iti me matiḥ
translated: Therefore, it is my opinion that Bhishma should be especially protected.

original: śikhaṇḍino vadhe yattāḥ sarve tiṣṭhantu māmakāḥ
analyzed: śikhaṇḍinaḥ vadhe yattāḥ sarve tiṣṭhantu māmakāḥ
translated: Let all my soldiers stand ready to kill Shikhandi.

analyzed: tathā prācyāḥ pratīcyāḥ ca dākṣiṇātya uttarāpathāḥ
translated: And let the easterners, westerners, southerners and northerners,

analyzed: sarva śastra astra kuśalāḥ te rakṣantu pitāmaham
translated: skilled in all weapons and missiles, protect the grandfather.

original: arakṣyamāṇaṃ hi vṛko hanyāt siṃhaṃ mahābalam
analyzed: a rakṣyamāṇam hi vṛkaḥ hanyāt siṃham mahā balam
translated: For a wolf might kill a very powerful lion if it is unprotected.

analyzed: mā siṃham jambukena iva ghātayāmaḥ śikhaṇḍinā
translated: Let us not have the lion killed by the jackal, namely Shikhandi.

original: vāmaṃ cakraṃ yudhāmanyur uttamaujāś ca dakṣiṇam
analyzed: vāmam cakram yudhāmanyuḥ uttamaujāḥ ca dakṣiṇam
translated: Yudhamanyu will guard the left wheel and Uttamauja the right wheel.

analyzed: goptārau phalgunasya etau śikhaṇḍinaḥ
translated: These two will protect Phalguna, and Phalguna will protect Shikhandi.

analyzed: saṃrakṣyamāṇaḥ pārthena bhīṣmeṇa ca vivarjitaḥ
translated: Protected by Partha and free from Bhishma,

original: yathā na hanyād gāṅgeyaṃ duḥśāsana tathā kuru
analyzed: yathā na hanyāt gāṅgeyam duḥśāsana tathā kuru
translated: O Duhshasana, act in such a way that he does not kill the son of Ganga.

original: tato rajanyāṃ vyuṣṭāyāṃ śabdaḥ samabhavan mahān
analyzed: tatas rajanyām vyuṣṭāyām śabdaḥ samabhavat mahān
translated: Then, when night had passed, a great sound arose,

analyzed: krośatām bhūmipālānām yujyatām yujyatām iti
translated: The kings shouted, Equip! Equip!

analyzed: śaṅkha dundubhi nirghoṣaiḥ siṃhanādaiḥ ca bhārata
translated: O descendant of Bharata, with the sounds of conch shells and drums, the roars of lions,

analyzed: haya heṣita śabdaiḥ ca ratha nemi svanaiḥ tathā
translated: The neighing of horses, the sounds of chariot wheels,

analyzed: gajānām bṛṃhatām ca eva yodhānām ca abhigarjatām
translated: The trumpeting of elephants, and the shouts of the warriors,

analyzed: kṣveḍita āsphoṭita utkruṣṭaiḥ tumulam sarvatas bhavat
translated: There was a tumultuous noise everywhere, with cries, slaps, and cheers.

analyzed: udatiṣṭhat mahā rāja sarvam yuktam aśeṣatas
translated: O great king, everything was ready without exception.

analyzed: sūrya udaye mahat sainyam kuru pāṇḍava senayoḥ
translated: At sunrise, the great armies of the Kuru and Pandava forces

original: tava rājendra putrāṇāṃ pāṇḍavānāṃ tathaiva ca
analyzed: tava rāja indra putrāṇām pāṇḍavānām tathā eva ca
translated: Of your sons, O lord of kings, and of the Pandavas,

analyzed: duṣpradhṛṣyāṇi ca astrāṇi sa śastra kavacāni ca
translated: With invincible weapons, arms, and armor,

analyzed: tatas prakāśe sainyāni samadṛśyanta bhārata
translated: Then the armies were seen, O descendant of Bharata,

original: tvadīyānāṃ pareṣāṃ ca śastravanti mahānti ca

original: dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnam adharmo 'bhibhavaty uta🔽adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kulastriyaḥ
analyzed: dharme naṣṭe kulam kṛtsnam adharmaḥ bhibhavati uta  adharma abhibhavāt kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kulastriyaḥ
translated: When righteousness is destroyed, unrighteousness overwhelms the entire family.🔽Because of the overwhelming power of unrighteousness, O Kṛṣṇa, the women of the family become corrupted.

analyzed: strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya jāyate varṇa saṃkaraḥ
translated: When the women are corrupted, O Vṛṣṇi's descendant, there arises a mixture of castes.

analyzed: saṃkaraḥ narakāya eva kula ghnānām kulasya ca
translated: The mixture of castes leads to hell for those who destroy the family and the family itself.

original: patanti pitaro hy eṣāṃ luptapiṇḍodakakriyāḥ🔽doṣair etaiḥ kulaghnānāṃ varṇasaṃkarakārakaiḥ
analyzed: patanti pitaraḥ hi eṣām lupta piṇḍa udaka kriyāḥ  doṣaiḥ etaiḥ kula ghnānām varṇa saṃkara kārakaiḥ
translated: The ancestors of those whose offerings of balls of rice and water are interrupted fall down.🔽Because of these faults of those who destroy the family and cause a mixture of castes,

analyzed: utsādyante jāti dharmāḥ kula dharmāḥ ca śāśvatāḥ
translated: The duties of caste and the eternal family duties are destroyed.

analyzed: utsanna kula dharmāṇām manuṣyāṇām janārdana
translated: O Janārdana, we have heard that for men whose family duties are destroyed,

analyzed: narake niyatam vāsaḥ bhavati iti anuśuśruma
translated: Dwelling in hell is certain.

original: aho bata mahat pāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam
analyzed: aho bata mahat pāpam kartum vyavasitāḥ vayam
translated: Alas! We are determined to commit a great sin,

original: yad rājyasukhalobhena hantuṃ svajanam udyatāḥ🔽yadi mām apratīkāram aśastraṃ śastrapāṇayaḥ
analyzed: yat rājya sukha lobhena hantum sva janam udyatāḥ  yadi mām apratīkāram aśastram śastra pāṇayaḥ
translated: that out of greed for the happiness of kingship, we are ready to kill our own relatives.🔽If the sons of Dhritarashtra, with weapons in hand, were to kill me in battle, unarmed and without any means of defense,

original: dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyus tan me kṣemataraṃ bhavet
analyzed: dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ raṇe hanyuḥ tat me kṣemataram bhavet
translated: that would be better for me.

analyzed: evam uktvā arjunaḥ saṃkhye rathopasthe upāviśat
translated: Having said this, Arjuna sat down on the chariot platform,

analyzed: visṛjya sa śaram cāpam śoka saṃvigna mānasaḥ
translated: putting aside his bow and arrows, his mind overwhelmed with grief.

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca
translated: Sanjaya said:

analyzed: tam tathā kṛpayā āviṣṭam aśru pūrṇa ākula īkṣaṇam
translated: To him, his eyes filled with tears of compassion and confusion,

analyzed: viṣīdantam idam vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ
translated: and despondent, Madhusudana spoke these words:

analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṃ viṣame samupasthitam
analyzed: kutas tvā kaśmalam idam viṣame samupasthitam
translated: From where has this cowardice come upon you at this critical moment?

analyzed: an ārya juṣṭam asvargyam a kīrti karam arjuna
translated: It is not worthy of the noble, it leads to heaven, and it brings fame, O Arjuna.

original: klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate
analyzed: klaibyam mā sma gamaḥ pārtha na etat tvayi upapadyate
translated: Do not give in to this weakness, O son of Pritha, it does not befit you.

analyzed: kṣudram hṛdaya daurbalyam tyaktvā uttiṣṭha paraṃtapa
translated: Cast aside this meanness of heart, which is a sign of weakness, and rise up, O scorcher of enemies.

original: arjuna uvāca🔽kathaṃ bhīṣmam ahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana
analyzed: arjunaḥ uvāca  katham bhīṣmam aham saṃkhye droṇam ca madhusūdana
translated: Arjuna said:🔽How can I, O slayer of Madhu, fight in battle with arrows

analyzed: iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjā arhau ari sūdana
translated: against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of my homage, O destroyer of enemies?

original: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvāñ /🔽śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣam apīha loke
analyzed: gurūn a hatvā hi mahā anubhāvān  śreyaḥ bhoktum bhaikṣam api iha loke
translated: For not having killed the greatly powerful elders,🔽It is better to enjoy even alms in this world,

analyzed: hatvā artha kāmān tu gurūn iha eva
translated: But having killed the elders who desire wealth in this very world,

analyzed: bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira pradigdhān
translated: I would enjoy pleasures tainted with blood.

original: na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo /
analyzed: na ca etat vidmaḥ katarat naḥ garīyaḥ
translated: We do not know which of these is weightier,

original: yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ
analyzed: yat vā jayema yadi vā naḥ jayeyuḥ
translated: Whether we would conquer or they would conquer us,

analyzed: yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas
translated: Having killed whom we would not wish to live.

analyzed: te vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ
translated: Those very ones, the sons of Dhritarashtra,

analyzed: kārpaṇya doṣa upahata svabhāvaḥ
translated: Are standing in front, their nature overcome by the fault of miserliness.

analyzed: pṛcchāmi tvām dharma saṃmūḍha cetāḥ
translated: My mind is confused about dharma, I ask you,

original: yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṃ brūhi tan me /
analyzed: yat śreyaḥ syāt niścitam brūhi tat me
translated: Tell me decisively what would be best for me.

original: śiṣyas te 'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam🔽na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād /
analyzed: śiṣyaḥ te ham śādhi mām tvām prapannam  na hi prapaśyāmi mama apanudyāt
translated: I am your disciple, instruct me, I have come to you for refuge.🔽For I do not see anything that would remove this grief

original: yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām🔽avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṃ /
analyzed: yat śokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām  avāpya bhūmau asapatnam ṛddham
translated: Which is drying up my senses, having obtained

analyzed: rājyam surāṇām api ca ādhipatyam
translated: Sovereignty on earth free from rivals and even lordship over the gods.

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca
translated: Sanjaya said

analyzed: evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśam guḍākeśaḥ paraṃtapa
translated: Having thus spoken to Hrishikesha, Gudakesha, the scorcher of enemies,

original: na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha
analyzed: na yotsye iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīm babhūva ha
translated: Having said to Govinda, I will not fight, remained silent.

original: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata
analyzed: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasan iva bhārata
translated: Hrishikesha spoke to him, as if smiling, O descendant of Bharata,

original: senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṃ vacaḥ
analyzed: senayoḥ ubhayoḥ madhye viṣīdantam idam vacaḥ
translated: In the midst of both armies, despondent, spoke these words:

analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṃ prajñāvādāṃś ca bhāṣase
analyzed: a śocyān anvaśocaḥ tvam prajñā vādān ca bhāṣase
translated: You grieve for those who are not to be grieved for, and you speak words of wisdom.

analyzed: gatāsūn agatāsūn ca na anuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
translated: The wise do not grieve for those who have departed or who have not departed.

analyzed: tvam mānuṣyeṇa upahata antarātmā  viṣāda moha abhibhavāt visaṃjñaḥ
translated: Your inner self is afflicted by humanity,🔽overcome by despondency and delusion, you have lost consciousness.

analyzed: kṛpā gṛhītaḥ samavekṣya bandhūn
translated: Seized by compassion, looking at your relatives

analyzed: abhiprapannān mukham antakasya
translated: who have fallen into the mouth of death,

original: na tv evāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ
analyzed: na tu eva aham jātu na āsam na tvam na ime janādhipāḥ
translated: But I never was not, nor were you, nor these Lords of the people;

original: na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param
analyzed: na ca eva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam atas param
translated: Nor in the future shall we all cease to be.

original: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā
analyzed: dehinaḥ u smin yathā dehe kaumāram yauvanam jarā
translated: As in this body, youth, adulthood and old age occur to the embodied being,

original: tathā dehāntaraprāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
analyzed: tathā deha antara prāptiḥ dhīraḥ tatra na muhyati
translated: So also the attainment of another body; the wise one is not deluded there.

analyzed: mātrā sparśāḥ tu kaunteya śīta uṣṇa sukha duḥkha dāḥ
translated: But the contacts of the senses, O son of Kunti, give rise to cold, heat, pleasure and pain.

analyzed: āgama apāyinaḥ nityāḥ tān titikṣasva bhārata
translated: They are impermanent and subject to coming and going; bear with them, O descendant of Bharata.

original: yaṃ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha
analyzed: yam hi na vyathayanti ete puruṣam puruṣa ṛṣabha
translated: For that man, O best of men, whom these do not afflict,

analyzed: sama duḥkha sukham dhīram saḥ mṛta tvāya kalpate
translated: The patient one, for whom pain and pleasure are the same, he is fit for immortality.

original: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ
analyzed: na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ na abhāvaḥ vidyate sataḥ
translated: From the non-existent, existence is not known; from the existent, non-existence is not known.

original: ubhayor api dṛṣṭo 'ntas tv anayos tattvadarśibhiḥ
analyzed: ubhayoḥ api dṛṣṭaḥ ntaḥ tu anayoḥ tattva darśibhiḥ
translated: But the wise have seen the end of both.

original: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṃ tatam
analyzed: avināśi tu tat viddhi yena sarvam idam tatam
translated: Know that to be indestructible by which this all is pervaded.

original: vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaś cit kartum arhati
analyzed: vināśam avyayasya asya na kaḥ cit kartum arhati
translated: No one can cause destruction of this imperishable one.

analyzed: antavantaḥ ime dehāḥ nityasya uktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ
translated: These bodies of the embodied one are said to be perishable.

analyzed: anāśino prameyasya tasmāt yudhyasva bhārata
translated: Therefore, O descendant of Bharata, fight.

original: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaś cainaṃ manyate hatam
analyzed: yaḥ enam vetti hantāram yaḥ ca enam manyate hatam
translated: He who knows Him as the killer and he who thinks Him as killed,

original: ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate
analyzed: ubhau tau na vijānītaḥ na ayam hanti na hanyate
translated: both of them do not know. He does not kill and is not killed.

original: na jāyate mriyate vā kadā cin /
analyzed: na jāyate mriyate vā kadā cit
translated: Never is this unborn destroyed.

original: nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ
analyzed: na ayam bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyas
translated: Nor does it become, nor is it born.

analyzed: ajaḥ nityaḥ śāśvataḥ yam purāṇaḥ
translated: This unborn, eternal, everlasting, ancient one.

analyzed: na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
translated: Is not killed when the body is killed.

original: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enam ajam avyayam
analyzed: veda avināśinam nityam yaḥ enam ajam avyayam
translated: He who knows this unborn, imperishable one,

original: kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam
analyzed: katham sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kam ghātayati hanti kam
translated: O Partha, how can that man cause another to kill or be killed?

analyzed: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya
translated: Just as a man, having abandoned old clothes,

analyzed: navāni gṛhṇāti naraḥ parāṇi
translated: takes up new ones,

analyzed: tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāni
translated: in the same way, having abandoned old bodies,

analyzed: anyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī
translated: the embodied one goes to others, new ones.

original: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ🔽na cainaṃ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
analyzed: na enam chindanti śastrāṇi na enam dahati pāvakaḥ  na ca enam kledayanti āpaḥ na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
translated: Weapons do not cut him, fire does not burn him,🔽water does not moisten him, wind does not dry him.

analyzed: acchedyaḥ yam a dāhyaḥ yam a kledyaḥ śoṣyaḥ eva ca
translated: He is not to be cut, not to be burned, not to be moistened, not to be dried.

analyzed: nityaḥ sarva gataḥ sthāṇuḥ acalaḥ yam sanātanaḥ
translated: He is eternal, all-pervading, firm, unmoving, and ancient.

analyzed: avyaktaḥ yam acintyaḥ yam avikāryaḥ yam ucyate
translated: He is said to be unmanifest, inconceivable, and immutable.

analyzed: tasmāt evam viditvā enam na anuśocitum arhasi
translated: Therefore, knowing him thus, you should not grieve for him.

original: atha cainaṃ nityajātaṃ nityaṃ vā manyase mṛtam
analyzed: atha ca enam nitya jātam nityam vā manyase mṛtam
translated: And if you think him born eternally, or dead eternally,

original: tathāpi tvaṃ mahābāho nainaṃ śocitum arhasi
analyzed: tathā api tvam mahā bāho na enam śocitum arhasi
translated: even then, O mighty-armed one, you should not grieve for him.

original: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca
analyzed: jātasya hi dhruvaḥ mṛtyuḥ dhruvam janma mṛtasya ca
translated: For birth is certain for the born, and death is certain for the born.

original: tasmād aparihārye 'rthe na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
analyzed: tasmāt aparihārye rthe na tvam śocitum arhasi
translated: Therefore, for an inevitable thing, you should not grieve.

analyzed: avyakta ādīni bhūtāni vyakta madhyāni bhārata
translated: The beings have the unmanifest for their origin, the manifest for their middle, O descendant of Bharata,

analyzed: avyakta nidhanāni eva tatra kā paridevanā
translated: and the unmanifest for their end. What is there to lament in this?

analyzed: āścarya vat paśyati kaḥ cit enam
translated: Some see him as wonderful,

analyzed: āścarya vat vadati tathā eva ca anyaḥ
translated: and some speak of him as wonderful, and likewise others.

analyzed: āścarya vat ca enam anyaḥ śṛṇoti
translated: And some hear about him as wonderful.

original: śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaś cit
analyzed: śrutvā api enam veda na ca eva kaḥ cit
translated: But even having heard about him, no one knows him at all.

original: dehī nityam avadhyo 'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata
analyzed: dehī nityam avadhyaḥ yam dehe sarvasya bhārata
translated: This embodied soul is indestructible, O son of Bharata, in this body of all beings.

original: tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
analyzed: tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvam śocitum arhasi
translated: Therefore, you should not grieve for all beings.

original: svadharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi
analyzed: svadharmam api ca avekṣya na vikampitum arhasi
translated: And considering your own duty, you should not waver.

original: dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyo 'nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
analyzed: dharmyāt hi yuddhāt śreyaḥ nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
translated: For a kshatriya, there is nothing better than a righteous battle.

analyzed: yadṛcchayā ca upapannam svarga dvāram apāvṛtam
translated: And this has come to you by chance, the door to heaven opened wide.

original: sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
analyzed: sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
translated: Happy are the kshatriyas, O son of Pritha, who obtain such a battle.

original: atha cet tvam imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi
analyzed: atha ced tvam imam dharmyam saṃgrāmam na kariṣyasi
translated: But if you do not fight this righteous battle,

original: tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
analyzed: tatas svadharmam kīrtim ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
translated: then you will incur sin by abandoning your own duty and fame.

analyzed: akīrtim ca api bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te vyayām
translated: And beings will proclaim your imperishable infamy.

original: saṃbhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate🔽bhayād raṇād uparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ
analyzed: saṃbhāvitasya ca akīrtiḥ maraṇāt atiricyate  bhayāt raṇāt uparatam maṃsyante tvām mahā rathāḥ
translated: And for one who is esteemed, infamy is worse than death.🔽The great warriors will think of you as one who has desisted from battle out of fear.

original: yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
analyzed: yeṣām ca tvam bahu mataḥ bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
translated: And those who have esteemed you will think less of you.

analyzed: avācya vādān ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tava ahitāḥ
translated: And your enemies will speak many unpleasant words.

original: nindantas tava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim
analyzed: nindantaḥ tava sāmarthyam tatas duḥkhataram nu kim
translated: And they will censure your ability. What can be worse than that?

original: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm
analyzed: hataḥ vā prāpsyasi svargam jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm
translated: Slain, you will attain heaven; or, having conquered, you will enjoy the earth.

analyzed: tasmāt uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta niścayaḥ
translated: Therefore, O son of Kunti, rise up, resolved to fight.

analyzed: sukha duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābha alābhau jaya ajayau
translated: Having made happiness and sorrow, gain and loss, victory and defeat, equal,

original: tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpam avāpsyasi
analyzed: tatas yuddhāya yujyasva na evam pāpam avāpsyasi
translated: then engage in battle. In this way you will not incur sin.

original: eṣā te 'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṃ śṛṇu
analyzed: eṣā te bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiḥ yoge tu imām śṛṇu
translated: This understanding has been declared to you in the Sankhya system. Now listen to it in the Yoga system.

original: buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi
analyzed: buddhyā yuktaḥ yayā pārtha karma bandham prahāsyasi
translated: United with this understanding, O son of Pritha, you will abandon the bondage of action.

analyzed: na iha abhikrama nāśaḥ sti pratyavāyaḥ na vidyate
translated: Here there is no loss of exertion, nor is there any obstruction.

original: svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
analyzed: su alpam api asya dharmasya trāyate mahataḥ bhayāt
translated: Even a little of this dharma protects from great fear.

analyzed: vyavasāya ātmikā buddhiḥ ekā iha kuru nandana
translated: O son of Kunti, the understanding that is resolute is one here.

analyzed: bahu śākhāḥ hi anantāḥ ca buddhayaḥ vyavasāyinām
translated: For those who are irresolute, the understandings are many-branched and endless.

original: yām imāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ
analyzed: yām imām puṣpitām vācam pravadanti a vipaścitaḥ
translated: This flowery speech that the unwise utter,

analyzed: veda vāda ratāḥ pārtha na anyat asti iti vādinaḥ
translated: O son of Pritha, those who delight in the Vedic teachings, saying There is nothing else,

analyzed: kāma ātmānaḥ svarga parāḥ janma karma phala pradām
translated: whose souls are attached to desire, who are intent on heaven, which gives the fruits of birth and action,

analyzed: kriyā viśeṣa bahulām bhoga aiśvarya gatim prati
translated: which is full of various rites, for the attainment of enjoyment and lordship,

analyzed: bhoga aiśvarya prasaktānām tayā apahṛta cetasām
translated: for those whose minds are carried away by that, who are attached to enjoyment and lordship,

analyzed: vyavasāya ātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
translated: The intellect which is of the nature of determination is not enjoined in concentration.

analyzed: traiguṇya viṣayāḥ vedāḥ nistraiguṇyaḥ bhava arjuna
translated: The Vedas have the three qualities as their object. Be free from the three qualities, O Arjuna.

analyzed: nirdvaṃdvaḥ nitya sattva sthaḥ niryogakṣemaḥ ātmavān
translated: Free from the pairs of opposites, always abiding in goodness, free from anxiety about renunciation and acquisition, self-possessed,

analyzed: yāvān arthaḥ udapāne sarvatas saṃpluta udake
translated: As much as the purpose of a well is in water that is everywhere flooded,

original: tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ🔽karmaṇy evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadā cana
analyzed: tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ  karmaṇi eva adhikāraḥ te mā phaleṣu kadā cana
translated: So much is the purpose of all the Vedas for the brahmin who knows.🔽You have a right only to the action, never to its results.

original: mā karmaphalahetur bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stv akarmaṇi
analyzed: mā karma phala hetuḥ bhūḥ mā te saṅgo stu akarmaṇi
translated: Do not be the cause of the results of action, do not be attached to inaction.

original: yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā dhanaṃjaya
analyzed: yoga sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgam tyaktvā dhanaṃjaya
translated: Stationed in yoga, perform actions, abandoning attachment, O Dhananjaya.

original: siddhyasiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṃ yoga ucyate
analyzed: siddhi asiddhyoḥ samaḥ bhūtvā sama tvam yogaḥ ucyate
translated: Being the same in success and failure, equanimity is called yoga.

original: yasya sarve samārambhā nirāśīrbandhanās tv iha
analyzed: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ tu iha
translated: For one whose undertakings here are all without the bondage of desire for results,

original: tyāge yasya hutaṃ sarvaṃ sa tyāgī sa ca buddhimān
analyzed: tyāge yasya hutam sarvam sa tyāgī sa ca buddhimān
translated: for whom everything is offered in renunciation, he is the renouncer and the wise one.

original: dūreṇa hy avaraṃ karma buddhiyogād dhanaṃjaya
analyzed: dūreṇa hi avaram karma buddhi yogāt dhanaṃjaya
translated: For action is far inferior to the yoga of the intellect, O Dhananjaya.

analyzed: buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala hetavaḥ
translated: Seek refuge in the intellect, for those who are miserable are the cause of results.

analyzed: buddhi yuktaḥ jahāti iha ubhe sukṛta duṣkṛte
translated: One who is united with the intellect abandons here both good and bad deeds.

original: tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
analyzed: tasmāt yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
translated: Therefore, apply yourself to yoga. Yoga is skill in actions.

original: karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ
analyzed: karma jam buddhi yuktāḥ hi phalam tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: For the wise, whose actions are guided by wisdom, having renounced the fruits of action,

analyzed: janma bandha vinirmuktāḥ padam gacchanti anāmayam
translated: are freed from the bondage of birth and attain the state of health.

analyzed: yadā te moha kalilam buddhiḥ vyatitariṣyati
translated: When your mind will cross over the mire of delusion,

original: tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
analyzed: tadā gantāsi nirvedam śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
translated: then you will attain detachment from what is to be heard and what has been heard.

analyzed: śruti vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā
translated: When your mind, which is opposed to what is heard, will stand still,

original: samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
analyzed: samādhau acalā buddhiḥ tadā yogam avāpsyasi
translated: then your intellect will attain steadiness in concentration and you will attain yoga.

analyzed: arjunaḥ uvāca
translated: Arjuna said:

analyzed: sthita prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi sthasya keśava
translated: What is the speech of one whose wisdom is steady, O Keshava, of one who is established in concentration?

original: sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
analyzed: sthita dhīḥ kim prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
translated: What does the one of steady mind speak, what does he sit, what does he move about?

analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manogatān
analyzed: prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manaḥ gatān
translated: When one gives up all longings that are in the mind, O son of Prtha,

analyzed: ātmani eva ātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita prajñaḥ tadā ucyate
translated: and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is called one whose wisdom is steady.

analyzed: duḥkheṣu anudvigna manāḥ sukheṣu vigata spṛhaḥ
translated: One who is not agitated in sorrows, who is free from desire in pleasures,

analyzed: vīta rāga bhaya krodhaḥ sthita dhīḥ muniḥ ucyate
translated: who is free from attachment, fear and anger, he is called a sage of steady mind.

original: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tat tat prāpya śubhāśubham
analyzed: yaḥ sarvatra anabhisnehaḥ tat tat prāpya śubha aśubham
translated: He who is without attachment everywhere, who obtains good and bad,

original: nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
analyzed: na abhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
translated: who neither rejoices nor hates, his wisdom is well-established.

analyzed: yadā saṃharate ca ayam kūrmaḥ u ṅgāni iva sarvaśas
translated: When this one withdraws all the senses from their objects, like a tortoise its limbs,

analyzed: indriyāṇi indriya arthebhyaḥ tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
translated: then his wisdom is established.

analyzed: viṣayāḥ vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ
translated: The objects turn away from the embodied one who does not eat them.

original: rasavarjaṃ raso 'py asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
analyzed: rasa varjam asya param dṛṣṭvā nivartate
translated: Even the taste of taste turns away when the highest is seen.

original: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ
analyzed: yatataḥ hi api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ
translated: For even a person who is striving, O son of Kunti, who is wise,

analyzed: indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabham manaḥ
translated: the senses, which are violent, forcibly carry away the mind.

original: tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta matparaḥ
analyzed: tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yuktaḥ āsīta mad paraḥ
translated: But restraining all of them, one should sit absorbed, with Me as the supreme goal.

original: vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
analyzed: vaśe hi yasya indriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
translated: For the wisdom of one whose senses are under control is well established.

analyzed: dhyāyataḥ viṣayān puṃsaḥ saṅgaḥ teṣu upajāyate
translated: For a person who thinks about the objects, attachment to them arises.

analyzed: saṅgāt saṃjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodhaḥ bhijāyate
translated: From attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.

analyzed: krodhāt bhavati saṃmohaḥ saṃmohāt smṛti vibhramaḥ
translated: From anger, delusion comes; from delusion, confusion of memory.

analyzed: smṛti bhraṃśāt buddhi nāśaḥ buddhi nāśāt praṇaśyati
translated: From the loss of memory, the destruction of wisdom; from the destruction of wisdom, he perishes.

analyzed: rāga dveṣa viyuktaiḥ tu viṣayān indriyaiḥ caran
translated: But one who moves about with the senses and the objects, being detached from attachment and aversion,

analyzed: ātma vaśyaiḥ vidheya ātmā prasādam adhigacchati
translated: with the senses under control, with the self under control, attains tranquility.

analyzed: prasāde sarva duḥkhānām hāniḥ asya upajāyate
translated: In tranquility, the destruction of all sorrows arises for him.

analyzed: prasanna cetasaḥ hi āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
translated: For the mind of one who is tranquil soon becomes fixed in knowledge.

original: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā
analyzed: na asti buddhiḥ ayuktasya na ca ayuktasya bhāvanā
translated: There is no knowledge for one who is not self-controlled, nor is there meditation for one who is not self-controlled.

original: na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
analyzed: na ca abhāvayataḥ śāntiḥ aśāntasya kutas sukham
translated: And there is no peace for one who does not meditate, and how can there be happiness for one who is not at peace?

analyzed: indriyāṇām hi caratām yat manaḥ nuvidhīyate
translated: For when the mind follows after the wandering senses,

original: tad asya harati prajñāṃ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi🔽tasmād yasya mahābāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ
analyzed: tat asya harati prajñām vāyuḥ nāvam iva ambhasi  tasmāt yasya mahā bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśas
translated: it carries away his wisdom, like the wind a ship on the water.🔽Therefore, O mighty-armed one, for one who has completely restrained the senses from the objects of the senses,

original: indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā🔽yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī
analyzed: indriyāṇi indriya arthebhyaḥ tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā  yā niśā sarva bhūtānām tasyām jāgarti saṃyamī
translated: his wisdom is firmly established.🔽That is the night for all beings, during which the self-controlled one is awake.

original: yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ🔽āpūryamāṇam acalapratiṣṭhaṃ /
analyzed: yasyām jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyataḥ muneḥ  āpūryamāṇam acala pratiṣṭham
translated: That is the night for the sage who sees, during which all beings are awake.

analyzed: samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat
translated: Just as the waters enter the ocean, which is ever filled but never overflows,

analyzed: tadvat kāmāḥ yam praviśanti sarve
translated: in the same way all desires enter him,

analyzed: sa śāntim āpnoti na kāma kāmī
translated: but he attains peace, not one who is desirous of desires.

original: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṃś carati niḥspṛhaḥ
analyzed: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumān carati niḥspṛhaḥ
translated: The man who wanders about, free from desires, renouncing all desires,

analyzed: nirmamaḥ nirahaṃkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchati
translated: without a sense of ownership, without egotism, he attains peace.

original: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati
analyzed: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha na enām prāpya vimuhyati
translated: This is the state of Brahman, O son of Prtha; having attained this, one is not deluded.

analyzed: sthitvā asyām anta kāle brahma nirvāṇam ṛcchati
translated: Even at the time of death, if one is established in this, one attains the final liberation of Brahman.

analyzed: arjunaḥ uvāca
translated: Arjuna said:

original: jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana
analyzed: jyāyasī ced karmaṇaḥ te matā buddhiḥ janārdana
translated: If, O Janardana, you consider knowledge to be superior to action,

original: tat kiṃ karmaṇi ghore māṃ niyojayasi keśava
analyzed: tat kim karmaṇi ghore mām niyojayasi keśava
translated: then why do you engage me in terrible action, O Keshava?

analyzed: vyāmiśreṇa eva vākyena buddhim mohayasi iva me
translated: With a mixed statement, you seem to confuse my understanding.

original: tad ekaṃ vada niścitya yena śreyo 'ham āpnuyām
analyzed: tat ekam vada niścitya yena śreyaḥ ham āpnuyām
translated: Therefore, tell me decisively that by which I may attain the highest good.

analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: loke 'smin dvividhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayānagha
analyzed: loke smin dvividhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayā anagha
translated: In this world, O sinless one, the two kinds of devotion were spoken of by Me before:

analyzed: jñāna yogena sāṃkhyānām karma yogena yoginām
translated: The devotion of the Sāṅkhyas through the yoga of knowledge, and the devotion of the yogis through the yoga of action.

analyzed: na karmaṇām anārambhāt naiṣkarmyam śnute
translated: One does not attain freedom from action by not undertaking action.

original: na ca saṃnyasanād eva siddhiṃ samadhigacchati
analyzed: na ca saṃnyasanāt eva siddhim samadhigacchati
translated: Nor does one attain perfection merely by renunciation.

original: na hi kaś cit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarmakṛt
analyzed: na hi kaḥ cit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhati a karma kṛt
translated: For no one can remain even for a moment without performing action.

original: kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛtijair guṇaiḥ🔽karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya ya āste manasā smaran
analyzed: kāryate hi avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti jaiḥ guṇaiḥ  karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya yaḥ āste manasā smaran
translated: Everyone is forced to perform action by the qualities born of the material nature.

analyzed: indriya arthān vimūḍha ātmā mithyā ācāraḥ saḥ ucyate
translated: He who, restraining the organs of action with the mind, remains remembering the objects of the senses, with a deluded self, is said to be a hypocrite.

analyzed: yaḥ tu indriyāṇi manasā niyamya ārabhate rjuna
translated: But he, O Arjuna, who, restraining the organs of action with the mind,

analyzed: karmendriyaiḥ karma yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
translated: He who is unattached to the fruits of action, and is engaged in action with the organs of action, is superior.

original: niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ
analyzed: niyatam kuru karma tvam karma jyāyaḥ hi akarmaṇaḥ
translated: Always perform action that is to be performed; for action is better than inaction.

original: śarīrayātrāpi ca te na prasidhyed akarmaṇaḥ
analyzed: śarīra yātrā api ca te na prasidhyet a karmaṇaḥ
translated: Even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you if you were not to engage in action.

analyzed: yajña arthāt karmaṇaḥ nyatra lokaḥ yam karma bandhanaḥ
translated: This world is bound by action that is other than that which is for the sake of sacrifice.

analyzed: tad artham karma kaunteya mukta saṅgaḥ samācara
translated: Therefore, O son of Kunti, perform action for the sake of the self, being unattached and with the self under control.

analyzed: saha yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purā uvāca prajāpatiḥ
translated: Having created the people along with the sacrifices, the Lord of creatures said:

analyzed: anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vaḥ stu iṣṭa kāmadhuk
translated: By this you will increase; let this be your fulfiller of desired objects.

original: devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ
analyzed: devān bhāvayata anena te devāḥ bhāvayantu vaḥ
translated: By this you should honour the gods; let the gods honour you.

analyzed: parasparam bhāvayantaḥ śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha
translated: Honouring each other, you will attain the highest good.

original: iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajñabhāvitāḥ
analyzed: iṣṭān bhogān hi vaḥ devāḥ dāsyante yajña bhāvitāḥ
translated: The gods, being pleased by the sacrifice, will give you desired enjoyments.

original: tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
analyzed: taiḥ dattān a pradāya ebhyaḥ yaḥ bhuṅkte stenaḥ eva saḥ
translated: He who enjoys those given by them without giving to them is a thief.

analyzed: yajña śiṣṭa āśinaḥ santaḥ mucyante sarva kilbiṣaiḥ
translated: The virtuous, who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, are freed from all sins.

original: bhuñjate te tv aghaṃ pāpā ye pacanty ātmakāraṇāt
analyzed: bhuñjate te tu agham pāpāḥ ye pacanti ātma kāraṇāt
translated: But those sinners who cook for their own sake eat sin.

analyzed: annāt bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyāt anna saṃbhavaḥ
translated: From food beings originate; the origin of food is from rain;

analyzed: yajñāt bhavati parjanyaḥ yajñaḥ karma samudbhavaḥ
translated: From sacrifice comes rain; sacrifice is born of action.

analyzed: karma brahma udbhavam viddhi brahma akṣara samudbhavam
translated: Know that action is born of Brahman; Brahman is born of the imperishable.

original: tasmāt sarvagataṃ brahma nityaṃ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
analyzed: tasmāt sarva gatam brahma nityam yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
translated: Therefore, Brahman, which is all-pervading, is always established in sacrifice.

analyzed: evam pravartitam cakram na anuvartayati iha yaḥ
translated: He who does not follow this wheel, which has thus been set in motion,

original: aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṃ pārtha sa jīvati
analyzed: aghāyuḥ indriya ārāmaḥ mogham pārtha sa jīvati
translated: lives a fruitless life, O son of Pritha, with a short lifespan, indulging in the senses.

original: yas tv ātmaratir eva syād ātmatṛptaś ca mānavaḥ🔽ātmany eva ca saṃtuṣṭas tasya kāryaṃ na vidyate
analyzed: yaḥ tu ātma ratiḥ eva syāt ātma tṛptaḥ ca mānavaḥ  ātmani eva ca saṃtuṣṭaḥ tasya kāryam na vidyate
translated: But a man who finds delight only in the self, who is content with the self,🔽and who is satisfied with the self alone, has no duty to perform.

original: naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛteneha kaś cana
analyzed: na eva tasya kṛtena arthaḥ na akṛtena iha kaḥ cana
translated: He has no purpose in doing or not doing anything in this world.

original: na cāsya sarvabhūteṣu kaś cid arthavyapāśrayaḥ
analyzed: na ca asya sarva bhūteṣu kaḥ cit artha vyapāśrayaḥ
translated: And he has no dependence on anything for his purpose among all beings.

original: tasmād asaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara
analyzed: tasmāt asaktaḥ satatam kāryam karma samācara
translated: Therefore, always detached, one should perform one's duty.

original: asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ🔽karmaṇaiva hi saṃsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ
analyzed: asaktaḥ hi ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ  karmaṇā eva hi saṃsiddhim āsthitāḥ janaka ādayaḥ
translated: For a detached person, performing action, attains the highest.🔽For Janaka and others attained perfection only through action.

analyzed: loka saṃgraham eva api saṃpaśyan kartum arhasi
translated: Even considering the need to guide the world, you should perform action.

original: yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ
analyzed: yat yat ācarati śreṣṭhaḥ tat tat eva itaraḥ janaḥ
translated: Whatever the best person does, that the other people do.

original: sa yat pramāṇaṃ kurute lokas tad anuvartate
analyzed: sa yat pramāṇam kurute lokaḥ tat anuvartate
translated: Whatever standard he sets, the world follows.

original: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṃ triṣu lokeṣu kiṃ cana🔽nānavāptam avāptavyaṃ varta eva ca karmaṇi
analyzed: na me pārtha asti kartavyam triṣu lokeṣu kim cana  na anavāptam avāptavyam varte eva ca karmaṇi
translated: O son of Prtha, I have nothing to do in the three worlds,🔽nor is there anything to be obtained that has not been obtained; I am engaged in action.

original: yadi hy ahaṃ na varteyaṃ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ
analyzed: yadi hi aham na varteyam jātu karmaṇi atandritaḥ
translated: If I were not to engage in action at all times, being diligent,

analyzed: mama vartma anuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśas
translated: then men everywhere would follow my path, O son of Prtha.

original: utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṃ karma ced aham
analyzed: utsīdeyuḥ ime lokāḥ na kuryām karma ced aham
translated: These worlds would perish if I did not perform action;

original: saṃkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
analyzed: saṃkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
translated: I would be the cause of universal confusion and would destroy these people.

original: saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṃso yathā kurvanti bhārata
analyzed: saktāḥ karmaṇi a vidvāṃsaḥ yathā kurvanti bhārata
translated: As the ignorant perform action, O descendant of Bharata, being attached to it,

analyzed: kuryāt vidvān tathā asaktaḥ cikīrṣuḥ loka saṃgraham
translated: so should the wise one perform action, being detached, desiring to restrain the people.

analyzed: na buddhi bhedam janayet ajñānām karma saṅginām
translated: One should not cause a difference in the understanding of the ignorant who are attached to action.

analyzed: joṣayet sarva karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācaran
translated: The wise one, being engaged, should perform all actions as one who is indifferent.

analyzed: prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśas
translated: All actions are performed by the qualities of Nature in every way.

analyzed: ahaṃkāra vimūḍha ātmā kartāham iti manyate
translated: The one whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, I am the doer.

original: tattvavit tu mahābāho guṇakarmavibhāgayoḥ🔽guṇā guṇeṣu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate
analyzed: tattva vid tu mahā bāho guṇa karma vibhāgayoḥ  guṇāḥ guṇeṣu vartante iti matvā na sajjate
translated: But the one who knows the truth, O mighty-armed one, about the division of the qualities and actions,🔽thinking that the qualities act upon the qualities, does not become attached.
